posts.name: Brian Z
posts.cooked:
Hello CD ,

We’re encountering some issues with the CAN bus that we could use help with. Last year, we had 15 motors and other devices on our RIO CAN bus, and we learned the limits of the system. This year, we decided to invest in a CANivore to help distribute the load. Everything is wired up and detected in TunerX and the REV client, but we’re still facing problems.

During the robot’s boot-up, we receive a few errors: “Error -1001: Could not transmit CAN frame. Talon FX 1 (empty). Apply Config.” This error appears for all of our drive motors on the RIO CAN bus. Once the robot finishes booting, we see a lot of “Error -10021” messages saying the device firmware couldn’t be retrieved (check firmware and ID). These errors seem to originate from the CAN ID assigned to devices on the CANivore.

We are also receiving numerous “Error -1003: CAN frame not received/too stale” messages related to the same CANivore devices. I checked the CAN bus utilization in TunerX, and it’s around 7%. We only have four motors on the second bus, so I see no reason why we would be getting overloading or getting stale can frames.

I’ve searched through past posts about error -1003, and the only solution I’ve found is to check the firmware. Does anyone have any other suggestions or ideas? We’re stuck at this point, just trying to get the robot to run.

Here is a drive link to the log files from our last build meeting trying to get it working: Final test logs.zip - Google Drive

Thanks in advance!

posts.name: jim
posts.cooked: The canivore is only good for CTR devices. Also make sure you have the correct ohm resistor at the end of the line.

posts.name: Brian Z
posts.cooked: We have a 120 ohm resistor at the end of the run and we only have 4 Kraken X60s and a pigeon 2.0 on the CANivore

posts.name: Technologyman00
posts.cooked: Have you tried commenting out everything but one device in the code?

posts.name: Brian Z
posts.cooked: Yeah we get the same issue, its acting like the can bus is overloaded, the motor with id 4 is for our wrist rotation when I send the command to move to a set point the motor will spin but it will not stop because its not reporting the encoder counts.

posts.name: Brian Z
posts.cooked: Here is a link to our git repo for this year if it would assist in diagnosing the problem. I’m sorry the code is ugly lol GitHub - Team-8841/FRC-2025: Code for the 2025 season

link_counts.title: GitHub - Team-8841/FRC-2025: Code for the 2025 season

posts.name: Brian Z
posts.cooked: I have been looking around on old posts and found that we can change the polling rate on the motors. I’m not to sure if this would fix our issue. We are only at 7% utilization on our CANivore. Any thoughts?

posts.name: Benjamin Hall
posts.cooked:
BrianZ:

we only have 4 Kraken X60s and a pigeon 2.0 on the CANivore

This doesn’t match what I see in your code; I see both elevator motors (18 and 16), both gripper motors (3 and 4), and a CANdle (0) on a CANivore named “canivore”, but everything else (including the Pigeon 2.0) on the roboRIO bus.

Besides that, check that your device LEDs are not blinking or blipping red; if they are, then you have a CAN bus wiring issue. If they aren’t, check that all the devices in Tuner X are showing up and are on the expected CAN bus (listed in the bottom left). Also note that the default name of a CANivore is NOT “canivore”, so make sure you changed the name of it.

user_custom_fields.user_field_4: Software Engineering Intern at CTR Electronics

posts.custom_user_title: Software Engineering Intern at CTR Electronics

posts.name: Brian Z
posts.cooked: We finally fixed the issues. We ended up fully rewiring all of the CAN . We found a couple of suspect crimps going into the power poles and also found a missing screw on the green side of a power pole.
